We say that $M$ causally mediates the relationship between

$L$ and $T$ if the following sets of conditions are satisfied:

$$
\begin{aligned}
&1.\:L \propto T (L \text{ is associated with } T) \\

&2.\:L \propto (M|T)\\

&3.\:M \propto (T|L)\\

&4.\:L \perp (T|M) (L \text{ is independent of } (T|M))
\end{aligned}
$$


$$ E_{X\sim P_D}[E_{z\sim Q}[\log P(X|z)] - \mathcal{D}[Q(z | X) \parallel P(z)]]$$

$$ - \lambda \mathcal{D}[Q(z) \parallel P(z)] - E_{z \sim Q}[\mathcal{D}[Q(X|z) \parallel P(X|z)]] + \alpha I_Q (X;z)$$ 

$$
\begin{aligned}
&1.\:T = \alpha + \sum_{i=1}^z \beta_z L_z + \epsilon;\: \epsilon \sim N(0,\sigma^2)\\
&2.\:M = \alpha + \beta_T T + \sum_{i=1}^z \beta_z L_z + \epsilon;\: \epsilon \sim N(0,\sigma^2)\\
&3.\:T = \alpha + \beta_M M + \sum_{i=1}^z \beta_z L_z + \epsilon;\: \epsilon \sim N(0,\sigma^2)
\end{aligned}
$$
